2.1 Introduction

text:p.text:span: Multiple people want to buy something,
to give the store money, but they
. So they queue up at the
desk and wait for the clerk to finish the previous person.
The service desk is a bottleneck.
are full of queues, for the CPU, for I/O, for a page of memory and so on,
When things queue up, the machine gets slow.
As a result, they have been extensively studied by computer scientists and mathematicians,

office:text.text:p: There are single line, single-server queues., as illustrated in Figure 1.

draw:text-box.text:p: Figure 1: Customers queuing in a coffee-shop

office:text.text:p: And there are a host of others like:

text:list-item.text:p: multi-queue multi-server in grocery stores with multiple lines for multiple clerks,
single-queue multi-server, as in airports, with one interminable line but several clerks, and
the hated single-server, multi-queue one, when one lane of a two-lane highway is blocked and everyone has to merge into the same lane.

text:p.text:span: All of them come from having more work than workers, like the clerk
so the checkout desk is a bottleneck.

office:text.text:p: 2.2 Why Does Queuing Hurt?
It’s because queues are all a lot like a closed lane on a highway. Everyone has to wait while the cars at the head of the line squeeze themselves through a one-lane bottleneck.
If all the cars were lined up absolutely perfectly in two lanes, they could merge into a single lane without slowing down at all. We’d see something like Figure 2-2, a so-called “zipper” merge.

Of course, that’s terribly improbable. Unless traffic is very light, it’s arbitrarily hard to make everyone line up perfectly. So we get overlap. The more traffic, the more probability of overlap, until we get the merge in Figure 2-3.

text:p.text:span: All images have been proofed in gr
to be able to always said dark and light or solid or dotted.

office:text.text:p: In heavy traffic, there is no room. The first dark-colored car has to slow down to get behind the first light-colored one. The second light-colored car has to brake to avoid an accident, and all the rest of the light-colored cars have to brake and make spaces for the dark-colored cars. Or run the dark ones off the road.
That slows everyone, and the queue behind the bottleneck gets longer and longer.
2.3 Queues in Computers
In computers, you hear queues mentioned when someone is trying to plot the performance of a component, for example, a CPU.
Throughput

text:p.text:span: ou often see a throughput diagram, like the
along with a response time diagram, like

office:text.text:p:
The throughput graph rises steadily u
Figure 2-4: Textbook Graphs, Throughputntil around 80% of the maximum, then starts to level off, and finally becomes a horizontal straight line, but not until it’s at almost 20 requests per second, long past 10 requests per second.

This is what you will see from a load test, even though you might expect the graph to follow the lighter line and deliver 10 completed transactions per second (TPS) at a load of ten requests per second.
Instead, you can see the slowdown: at 10 requests a second, the program is only completing eight. At 17, it’s almost completing 10. For every higher load, it’s doing 10.

time that used to be 0.1 second is now almost a full second.

office:text.text:p: 2.4 Computer Queue Behavior

When we look at why the curves don’t have square corners we’ll look at queues. Computers are full of queues, and they are a big part of why computers slow down under load: queues build up like the merge diagrams above. Fortunately, processes don’t crash into one another like cars. Instead, for each CPU core they stack up, like processes two and three do in Figure 2-7.

In this diagram, the X axis is elapsed time, measured in tenths. The Y axis is delay caused by queuing. The solid color (green) area is time processes spent actually running on the CPU. The shaded (gray) area is time spent waiting to run.

Here, request number 3 has arrived at the Linux dispatcher just a bit after request 2 and created process 3. That process, however, can’t be run until process 2 has finished. Each process still takes one tenth of a second to get through the bottleneck, but some have to wait before they can do so, and therefore their total time is a lot longer.

text:p.text:span: This is not a very busy system. That means there are usually more tenths of a second than there are
requests arrive in the same tenth of a second do we have two processes trying to run at the same time. Only then do
a zipper merge with only a few
on the road, so there are lots of spaces

office:text.text:p: 2.5 When Does Probability Come Into It?
When things get busier.

text:p.text:span: Just like increasing road traffic makes a zipper merge less probable.
processes competing for a chance to run
, we get more and more chances
two processes want to run at the same time.

office:text.text:p: For example, when I did an experiment and chose four random numbers between 0.0 and 0.99 for arrival times, I got 0.12. 0.40, 0.83, and 0.93. When we draw that in the first (upper left) box of Figure 2-8, the boxes fall on a horizontal straight line.

text:p.text:span: we have a greater and greater chance

office:text.text:p: When I chose five random arrival times in the second (upper right) box, it looks a little busier. I got 0.00, 0.24, 0.33, 0.46 and 0.74. All but process 3 run immediately. Only it has to wait.

When I asked for eight random arrival times, however, I got the third box. There we see contention between all of the first four, the fifth and sixth, and the seventh and eighth. The time spent waiting in queue is much longer: instead of 0.01 second, we have spent 0.05 seconds for process four. The amount of time the processes spend running remains what you’d expect, 0.08 seconds, but the wait time rises to more than half that.

As the number of processes which arrive goes up, more conflict with each other, and the average time it takes for the processes to complete rises, until it’s approaching a straight line, shown in the last box. That’s what causes the dark (red) line in Figure 2-9to curl upwards.

draw:text-box.text:p: Figure 2-9: Response-time curve, copy of Figure 2-5

office:text.text:p: 2.6 Why the Delay isn’t Infinite
Probability doesn't just make things worse, though. It also keep us from failing on the very first overload.

Consider what would happen if we got 11 requests per second steadily. In the first second, we would do 10 requests, and the 11th would sit in queue and be delayed a tenth of a second. In the next second, there would be two processes in queue, delayed two tenths of a second. After three seconds, three-tenths of a second queuing delay. Every other process would be delayed too.

After a minute, we observe 6 seconds of queuing delay, for something that normally completes in one tenth of a second. After 10 minutes, 60 seconds of delay, and so on. The machine would be running, the lights would be flashing, but each human user would have to wait for a minute before they got a response, and then another minute for the next. To them “the lights are on, but nobody’s home”.

Fortunately, though, probability keeps that from happening. Every second, a few requests come in after a delay, like requests 5 and 7 in Figure 2-10. The queue falls back to zero, and then start to build again.

text:p.text:span: This is enough that machines don’t build up ever-increasing queue
, the queue may be madly building o
falling toward zero, but on average the delay will
. It will rise, as shown in
go straight up to infinity at 11 request per second.

text:p.text:span: how these parts all fit together, by looking

text:p.text:span: per second, they all fit perfectly, with no crumpled fenders. At 11 requests
request will be delayed by a tenth of a second, on average. Some will be delayed more, some
not at all, but general, they will be slowed by a tenth.

office:text.text:p: The 11th arrivals will all have to wait for the first request from the next second to complete, or vice versa. That time is shown here as light gray. In either case, the time taken will increase by a tenth of a second.

One is horizontal, at one tenth of a second, and the other slopes at a “rise over run” of 1 over 10, or one tenth.
They meet at 10 requests per second, often called the “
It is what you’d see if the requests were doing zipper merges and not having to wait.

office:text.text:p: 2.8 Drawing the Curves
Normally you’ll want to know the curve’s shape, so you use your understanding to keep the load below the point at which response time turns upwards.

To generate the curve, I use either the Java Modeling Tool suite, or more often, Neil Gunther’s PDQ (Pretty Darn Quick) queuing-network modeler. Specifically, I use Dr Gunther’s library via a little wrapper program that takes the service time, the sleep time and the range you want to report on.
For example, the curve above was created by running pdq -v -s 0.1 -z 0.9 1 20 1
where
-v is verbose
-s is the service time,
the range is from 1 to 20, in 1 request-per-second units.

text:p.text:span: Notice that I didn’t say before why the sleep time was 0.9. The explanation, for now, is that
having service and sleep times totaling one millisecond generates a good-looking hockey-stick curve.
We’ll see more in chapter 6, in the section on

office:text.text:p: 2.9 Using Your Knowledge
Let’s do a simple case which illustrated what we’re going to do in detail in subsequent chapters.

Consider a service that is normally takes or usual 100 milliseconds. We want to use it where we can’t afford it to take longer than 150 milliseconds. 150 milliseconds will be our “do not exceed” time.

text:p.text:span: With a model like the on
ou can look up the number of request
the line where the response time hits 0.15 seconds.
If we look at just the first six rows of that table, as
, we can look at response times around 0.15 seconds

office:text.text:p: Figure 2-12: Response time Under Load (Detail)

text:p.text:span: This shows that at 5 request a second, each will take 0.152 seconds. That

office:text.text:p: where the lighter (green) line is 100 milliseconds, and the darker (red) one is our do-not-exceed response time of 150 milliseconds.

As you see, the throughput of the 100 millisecond response time is higher that our do-not-exceed line, so we don’t want the throughput to fall below about seven completed requests per second, down from our current ten.
Looking at the data table, we see that a CPU core can deliver only 5 requests a second at or below 150 millisecond per transaction. That’s the bold-faced cell in Figure 2-12
That’s not very much. This is beginning to sound a little scary.

Now add that the customer needs 80 successful transactions a second (TPS). We need some headroom, so let’s add 20% to that and say we want to deliver 100 transactions per second. Now it definitely starts to sound scary...
Nope, it’s not!

text:p.text:span: We have lots of those in stock

office:text.text:p: Without a model, we would not have known, and we could have missed either high or low when we made a recommendation on how to fix the problem

text:p.text:span: too much money but deliver the service, or
can make a decent prediction of how much you will need to spend. Without one, you’

office:text.text:p: This is a classic illustration of a queuing model, and also an illustration that one’s initial thoughts can mislead, if we lack intuition and understanding. We’ll use this kind or analysis all through the book. It allow us is be predictive in a very unpredictable industry.
2.10 Summary
If you think back to Chapter 1, you can see what we were doing with the model in performance analysis.

text:p.text:span: how much slowdown to expect. That started us looking for
as soon as the model said
would be slower than we wanted.

office:text.text:p: That same focus on slowdowns from bottlenecks will be use in planning and development in Part IV, chapters 7 through 11.
But first we’ll stop talking about theory and jump straight to to the process of debugging problems using queues in Chapter 3, Diagnosis In the Heat of Battle.
